title.narrative: UNDP Bangladesh: Program för Mänskliga Rättigheter

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen omfattar stöd till UNDP Human Rights Programme 2015-2020 (Programmet). Programmet syftar till att bygga kapacitet hos centrala aktörer inom område mänskliga rättigheter i Bangladesh. Programmet omfattar stöd till statliga institutioner på området, med särskilt fokus på den nationella människorättskommissionen (NHRC/JAMAKON), Bangladeshs poliskår, samt insatser för att förbättra kapaciteten hos, och samverkan mellan, människorättsorganisationer inom det civila samhället I Bangladesh.
Detta beslut omfattar stöd under perioden 2015-2020 om totalt 37 miljoner kronor. Programmet inleds med en uppstartsfas (inception phase) om 18 månader under vilken bland annat en bedömning av NHRCs oberoende och kapacitet och övriga förutsättningar i förhållande till politisk risk skall göras. Resultatet av denna bedömning skall, tillsammans med Sidas bedömning av ett antal för programmet centrala dokument och strategier vilka skall framtas under denna fas, utgöra underlag för Sidas bedömning om fortsatt/avslutad finansiering för resterande programperiod. Detta skall utgöra avtalsvillkor (se avtal, Annex 2: Information Sheet: Inception Phase, UNDP Human Rights Programme, Bangladesh 2015-2020).
Övriga givare till programmet är Danmark och Schweiz. En programbaserad ansats skall användas. Modaliteten för UNDPs samarbete med Bangladesh regering utgörs av instrumentet Direct Execution, DEX. UNDP har därmed fullt ansvar för finansiell styrning och kontroll samt för implementering av programmet gentemot Sida.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The intervention at hand concerns UNDP Human Rights Programme 2015-2020 (henceforward the Programme). The Programme aims to build the capacity of existing human rights architectures in Bangladesh. The Programme will support state based institutions, in particular the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC), as well as undertake key civil society interventions to improve human rights coalitions across the country and work with central actors in the justice system with a particular focus on the Police. The NHRC is the main implementing partner for the program and the programme will work to strengthen the capacity of this central institution. It should however be noticed that the programme is broader than a capacity development support to the NHRC, and involves more actors/partnerships and activities that do not involve the NHRC. The Programme will be initiated by an 18 month inception phase, during which a review/evaluation of the commissions independence and capacity and other relevant conditions in relation to political risks will be assessed. The results of this shall, in combination with Sida’s assessment of a number of strategically relevant documents to be produced during this phase, serve as a foundation for decision on continued support for the remaining programme period. This shall constitute an agreement condition.
The Programme will be supported by Sweden, Switzerland and Denmark. A program based approach will be used.

The four-year programme aims to encourage and support the human rights and justice institutions with a special focus on the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) as well as other relevant stakeholders to approach policy development, service delivery and decision-making from a proactive human rights perspective. It has a particular focus on working with vulnerable and marginalized groups, including women and girls, children and young people, ethnic and religious minorities, people with disabilities, Dalit and other minorities. It will build gender equality initiatives, strengthen civil society activities for women and girls and build the position of the NHRC as an important partner for gender equality within Bangladesh.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
During 2020, in addition to the capacity strengthening of the trageted institutions and agencies, the Human Rights Programme (HRP) also made a significant contribution in advancing people's access to justice and legal aid services amid the COVID-19 pandemic situation. The programme's work resulted in the establishment of a 'virtual court' platform that increased the number of virtual hearings and ensured people's access to justice delivery systems in times of restricted movement due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
UNDP's training strengthened the capacity of human rights defenders which led to enhanced reporting on human rights violations during the pandemic. Based on these reports and factsheets, the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) provided recommendations to different government authorities, seeking rights-based COVID-19 response to address relevant issues.
Perceptions and attitudes of students aged between 11 and 15 years and teachers substantially changed as a result of interactive sessions on women's and girls' rights including prevention of violence of violence against women and girls. The campaign resulted in transformation from toxic to positive masculinity among 92.8% of adolescent boys comapred to a baseline of 41.1%.
Capacity development training to youth groups on gender, diversity, and gender-based violence resulted in the development and launch of a youth-led campaign on Women's Safety in Public Places.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
